question: Acetaminophen
answer:
Generic Name:Acetaminophen
Brand Name:Tylenol®, Abenol®, Acet®, Tempral®, Atasol®
Drug Class:Nonnarcotic Analgesic
Schedule:OTC
Indications:Pain, Fever
Dosage Forms:Tablet, Chewable Tablet, Suppository
Strengths:Supp: 120 mg, 160 mg, 325 mg, 650 mg. Chew tab: 80 mg, 160 mg. Tab: 160 mg, 325 mg, 500 mg, 650 mg. Solution: 80 mg/mL, 160 mg/5 mL
Dosing Interval:Variable
Common Adverse Effects:Derm: pruritis. GI: constipation, nausea, vomiting. CNS: headache, insomnia.
Other:Hepatotoxicity may occur after ingestion of a single dose of more than 7.5 g (adults) or 150 mg/kg (children); a dose of 10 g or more is potentially fatal in an adult. Acetylcysteine used in acute overdose. Because of the risk of toxicity, dosing for children must not exceed 5 doses in 24 hours unless under the advice of a physician.

question: Acetaminophen / Caffeine / Codeine
answer:
Generic Name:Acetaminophen / Caffeine / Codeine
Brand Name:Exdol®, Acet 2®, Acet 3®, Tylenol with Codeine®, Novo-Gesic C®
Drug Class:Opiate Analgesic Combination
Schedule:CDSA I
Indications:Pain
Dosage Forms:Tablet, Elixir
Strengths:325/30/8 mg, 325/30/15 mg, 325/30/30 mg, 300 mg
Dosing Interval:Every 4 Hours, Every 6 Hours
Common Adverse Effects:Most frequent adverse effects: drowsiness, lightheadedness, dizziness, sedation, shortness of breath, nausea, vomiting (more prominent in ambulatory patients). Constipation and abdmonial pain are common.
Other:Monitor total acetaminophen intake (including other acetaminophen-containing products) to assure maximum dose is not exceeded. CNS effects enhanced by other CNS depressants.

question: Acetylsalicylic Acid (Aspirin)
answer:
Generic Name:Acetylsalicylic Acid (Aspirin)
Brand Name:Asaphen®, Bufferin®, Entrophen®, Novasen ECT®, Anacin®
Drug Class:Salicylate NSAID
Schedule:OTC
Indications:Antiplatelet agent; pain, fever, inflammation
Dosage Forms:Tablet, Chewable Tablet, Suppository
Strengths:supp: 150 mg, 650 mg. chew tab: 80 mg. tab: 75 mg, 81 mg, 162 mg, 325 mg , 500 mg, 650 mg, 975 mg
Dosing Interval:Variable
Common Adverse Effects:GI: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, dyspepsia, bleeding and/or ulceration. CNS: tinnitus occurs with large doses.
Other:NSAIDs (reversible COX inhibitors) may interfere with antplatelet effects of aspirin via competative inhibition. When used for antiplatelet effects, aspirin should be taken 30-120 minutes before a NSAID. Do not use in children/teens with viral ifection (risk of Reye's syndrome). Contraindicated in last trimester of pregnancy.

question: Alendronate
answer:
Generic Name:Alendronate
Brand Name:Fosamax®
Drug Class:Bisphosphonate
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Osteoporosis, Paget's Disease of the Bone
Dosage Forms:Tablet, Oral Solution
Strengths:40 mg, 70 mg, 70 mg/75 mL
Dosing Interval:Once Daily, Once Weekly
Common Adverse Effects:Upper GI disorders (dysphagia, esophagitis, esophageal ulcer and gastric ulcer may occur), musculoskeletal pain, abdominal pain, dyspepsia and nausea, diarrhea.
Other:Should be taken on an empty stomach at least 30 minutes before consuming the first food, drink (other than plain water) and/or any other medication of the day. Food, medication or drink other than plain water can interfere with the absorption.

question: Allopurinol
answer:
Generic Name:Allopurinol
Brand Name:Zyloprim®, Alloprin®, Teva-Purol®
Drug Class:Xanthine Oxidase Inhibitor
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Gout
Dosage Forms:Tablet
Strengths:100 mg, 200 mg,
Dosing Interval:Once Daily, Twice Daily, Three Times Daily, (Doses >300 mg should be divided)
Common Adverse Effects:Skin rash (including Stevens-Johnson syndrome), usually maculopapular, is the most commonly reported adverse effect. Incidence of skin rash may be increased with renal disorders. GI (Diarrhea, intermittent abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting) side effects are common.
Other:Better tolerated when taken with food. Dosage adjustment required in renal dysfunction.

question: Amitriptyline
answer:
Generic Name:Amitriptyline
Brand Name:Elavil®, Levate®, Teva-Tryptin®
Drug Class:Tricyclic antidepressant
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Depression, Unlabeled uses: pain, migraine prophyaxis, neuropathy
Dosage Forms:Tablet
Strengths:10 mg, 25 mg, 50 mg, 75 mg
Dosing Interval:Once Daily, usually taken HS
Common Adverse Effects:Anticholinergic: dry mouth, urinary retention, constipation. CNS: drowsiness, fatigue. CV: othostatic hypotension, tachycardia. Weight gain is common.
Other:Extremely toxic in overdose: arrhythmia, hypotension, seizures, acidosis. Drug interactions common: CYP 2D6 substrate.

question: Amlodipine
answer:
Generic Name:Amlodipine
Brand Name:Norvasc®
Drug Class:Calcium Channel Blocker (Dihydropiridine)
Schedule:PDL
Indications:HTN, chronic stable angina
Dosage Forms:Tablet
Strengths:2.5 mg, 5 mg, 10 mg
Dosing Interval:Once Daily
Common Adverse Effects:CV: edema, postural dizziness. CNS: Headache. GI: has been associated with gingical hyperplasia.
Other:Available in combination with atorvastatin (Caduet). Drug interactions: CYP 3A4 substrate.

question: Amoxicillin
answer:
Generic Name:Amoxicillin
Brand Name:Tevamoxin®, Pro-Amox®, Nu-Amoxi®
Drug Class:Antibiotic (Semisynthetic Penicillin)
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Bacterial infection: Upper respiratiry tract. Lower respiratory tract, UTI, H pylori, Lyme disease
Dosage Forms:Capsule, Oral Suspesion, Chewable Tablet
Strengths:125 mg/5 mL, 250 mg/5 mL, 125 mg, 250 mg, 500 mg
Dosing Interval:Every 8 Hours, single dose for endocarditis prevention (prior to procedure)
Common Adverse Effects:Derm: allergic rash (usually erythematous, urticarial, may be maculopapular); incidence increased in mononucleosis. GI: nausea, vomiting, diarrhea. Renal: has been associated with acute interstitial neprhitis (uncommon).
Other:Probenecid inhibits renal tubular excretion (↑ amoxicillin concentrations). Associated with decreased oral contraceptive efficacy by reducing bacteria responsible for enterohepatic recirculation of estrogen.

question: Atenolol
answer:
Generic Name:Atenolol
Brand Name:Tenormin®, Nu-Atenol®
Drug Class:Beta blocker (β-1 selective)
Schedule:PDL
Indications:HTN, angina, secondary prevention post MI
Dosage Forms:Tablet
Strengths:25 mg, 50 mg, 100 mg
Dosing Interval:Once Daily, Twice Daily
Common Adverse Effects:Resp: broconchospasm. CV: hypotension, worsening of HF, bradycardia, heart block. CNS: fatigue, depression. Other: sexual dysfunction in males.
Other:Drug interactions: use with caution with other negative chronotropes (nondihydroipyridine CCBs, digoxin, Class I antiarrhythmics, amiodarone). If used in combination with clonidine, β-blocker should be withdrawn before stopping clonidine (overstimulation of upregulated β-receptors upon clonidine withdrawal may exacerbate rebound HTN).

question: Atorvastatin
answer:
Generic Name:Atorvastatin
Brand Name:Lipitor®
Drug Class:Antihyperlipidemic Agent (HMG-CoA Reductase Inhibitor)
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Dyslipidemia
Dosage Forms:Tablet
Strengths:10 mg, 20 mg, 40 mg, 80 mg
Dosing Interval:Once Daily
Common Adverse Effects:Skeletal: musculoseketal pain, rhabdomyolysis (rare), GI: liver funtion abnormalities.
Other:Available in combination with amlodipine (Caduet). Drug interactions: CYP 3A4 substrate. Use with caution with other agents associated with myopathy/rhabdomyolysis (e.g., fibric acid derivatives).

question: Azithromycin
answer:
Generic Name:Azithromycin
Brand Name:Zithromax®, Zmax SR®
Drug Class:Antibiotic (macrolide)
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Bacterial infection: Upper and lower respiratory tract infection, STD (chlamydia, gonorrhea), uncomplicated skin soft tissue, prevention of MAC
Dosage Forms:Tablet, Injection, Oral Suspesion, Granules
Strengths:250 mg, 600 mg, 100 mg/5 mL, 200 mg/5 mL, 500 mg vial for injection
Dosing Interval:Once Daily, single dose for chlamydia, once weekly for MAC prophylaxis
Common Adverse Effects:GI: loose stools/diarrhea, nausea, vomiting.
Other:The 250 mg tablets are available in a unit-of-use package known as Z-Pak (duration of therapy 5 days). Zmax SR contains sustained release granules for oral suspention.

question: Bisoprolol
answer:
Generic Name:Bisoprolol
Brand Name:Monocor®
Drug Class:Beta blocker (β-1 selective)
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Hypertension, heart failure, angina
Dosage Forms:Tablet
Strengths:5 mg, 10 mg
Dosing Interval:Once Daily
Common Adverse Effects:Resp: broconchospasm. CV: hypotension, worsening of HF, bradycardia, heart block. CNS: fatigue, depression. Other: sexual dysfunction in males.
Other:Heart failure and angina are not approved indications in Canada. Drug interactions: use with caution with other negative chronotropes (nondihydroipyridine CCBs, digoxin, Class I antiarrhythmics, amiodarone). If used in combination with clonidine, β-blocker should be withdrawn before stopping clonidine (overstimulation of upregulated β-receptors upon clonidine withdrawal may exacerbate rebound HTN).

question: Budesonide / Formoterol
answer:
Generic Name:Budesonide / Formoterol
Brand Name:Symbicort®, Symbicort Forte®
Drug Class:Corticosteroid / Long Acting Beta Agonist
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Asthma, COPD
Dosage Forms:DPI
Strengths:100 mcg/6 mcg, 200 mcg/6 mcg, 400 mgc/12 mcg
Dosing Interval:Twice Daily
Common Adverse Effects:Cardiac: palpitations. CNS: Headache, tremor. Infection: oral candidiasis (thrush). ENT: cough, hoarseness.
Other:Asthma indication for age 12 and above. LABA may increase risk of asthma related death, particularly in pediatric and adolescent patients. Counsel patients to rinse mouth after use.

question: Bupropion
answer:
Generic Name:Bupropion
Brand Name:Wellbutrin®, Wellbutrin SR®, Wellbutrin XL®, Zyban®
Drug Class:Antidepressant (aminoketone)
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Depression, seasonal affective disorder (SAD), smoking cessation
Dosage Forms:ER Tablet
Strengths:100 mg SR, 150 mg SR, 150 mg XL, 300 mg XL
Dosing Interval:Once Daily, Twice Daily, Three Times Daily, depending on dosage form
Common Adverse Effects:Cardiac: tachycardia. CNS: headache, insomnia, dizziness. GI: dry mouth, constipation, nausea. EENT: tinnitus.
Other:SR formulation dosed BID; XL formulation dosed once daily. Drug interactions:bupropion inhibits CYP 2D6--use with caution in combination with 2D6 substrates. Co-administration of thioridazine (QTc prolongation) and MAO inhibitors is contraindicated.

question: Candesartan
answer:
Generic Name:Candesartan
Brand Name:Atacand®
Drug Class:Angiotensin II Receptor Antagonist
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Hypertension, heart failure
Dosage Forms:Tablet
Strengths:4 mg, 8 mg, 16 mg, 32 mg
Dosing Interval:Once Daily
Common Adverse Effects:CV: syncope, hypotension. Electrolytes: hyperkalemia. Renal: renal impairment.
Other:Also available combined with HCTZ (Atacand Plus). Drug interactions: potassium/potassium sparing diuretics, NSAIDs (decreased candesartan efficacy and increased risk of renal dysfunction). Avoid in pregnancy (contraindicated in 2nd and 3rd trimesters).

question: Celecoxib
answer:
Generic Name:Celecoxib
Brand Name:Celebrex®
Drug Class:Antiinflammatory (NSAID)
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Rheumatoid arthritis, osteoarthritis, acute pain, ankylosing spondylitis
Dosage Forms:Capsule
Strengths:100 mg, 200 mg, 300 mg
Dosing Interval:Twice Daily
Common Adverse Effects:CV: Peripheral edema. CNS: dizziness, insomnia. GI: abdominal pain, diarrhea, dyspepsia, nausea, vomiting.
Other:Celecoxib is a specific inhibitor of cyclooxygenase-2. May increase the risk of CV events. Cross sensitivity with sulfonamides.

question: Cephalexin
answer:
Generic Name:Cephalexin
Brand Name:Keflex® Apo-Cephalex®
Drug Class:Antibiotic (cephalosporin)
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Uncomplicated skin/soft tissue infection, URI, acute cystitis
Dosage Forms:Tablet, Capsule, Oral Suspesion
Strengths:250 mg, 500 mg, 125 mg/5 mL, 250 mg/5 mL
Dosing Interval:Four Times Daily, Every 6 Hours
Common Adverse Effects:GI: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea (usually transient and mild). Has been associated with serum sickness-like reactions.
Other:Drug interaction: probenecid inhibits tubular secretion and decreases cephalexin elimination.

question: Ciprofloxacin
answer:
Generic Name:Ciprofloxacin
Brand Name:Cipro®, Cipro XL®, Ciloxan®
Drug Class:Antibiotic (fluoroquinolone)
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Respiratory tract infection, UTI, prostatitis, skin/soft tissue infection, bone/joint infection, infectious diarrhea, gonorrhea
Dosage Forms:Tablet, ER Tablet, Injection, Ophthalmic Solution, Oral Suspesion, Ophthalmic Ointment
Strengths:250 mg, 500 mg, 750 mg, 500 mg XL, 1000 mg XL, 500 mg/5 mL, 0.3% ophth, 200 mg/mL inj
Dosing Interval:Twice Daily, single dose for gonorrhea
Common Adverse Effects:GI: nausea, diarrhea. CNS: dizziness, nervousness, insomnia. May cause seizures in predisposed individuals. May cause photosensitivity.
Other:Each package for oral suspension contains microcapsules of ciprofloxacin along with a diluent. Water should not be used to form the suspension. Cipro Oral Suspension is stable for 14 days when stored under refrigeration or at room temperature. Drug interactions: potent inhibitor of CYP 1A2. May cause muscle weakness in patients with myesthenia gravis. Reports of tendon rupture. Safety under age 18 not established.

question: Citalopram
answer:
Generic Name:Citalopram
Brand Name:Celexa®
Drug Class:Antidepressant (Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitor)
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Depression
Dosage Forms:Tablet
Strengths:10 mg, 20 mg, 40 mg
Dosing Interval:Once Daily
Common Adverse Effects:CNS: insomnia, somnolence. GI: nausea, diarrhea, dry mouth. CV: postural hypotension, tachycardia. GU: sexual dysfunction, decreased libido.
Other:Citalopram is a racemic mixture. The S-isomer is responsible for antidepressant effects, while the R-isomer may contribute to adverse effects. Drug interactions: use with caution with other agents that prolong QTc and agents that increase serotonin. Citalopram is a substrate for CYP 2C19 and 3A4--overall risk of interactions is low.

question: Clarithromycin
answer:
Generic Name:Clarithromycin
Brand Name:Biaxin®, Biaxin XL®
Drug Class:Antibiotic (macrolide)
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Upper and lower respiratory tract infection, skin/soft tissue infection, Mycobacterium avium complex
Dosage Forms:Tablet, ER Tablet, Oral Suspesion
Strengths:250 mg, 500 mg, 500 mg XL, 125 mg/5 mL, 250 mg/5 mL
Dosing Interval:Once Daily, Twice Daily, depending on dosage form
Common Adverse Effects:GI: taste disturbance, diarrhea, vomiting, nausea. CNS: headache.
Other:Biaxin oral suspension maintains stability for 14 days when stored at room temperature – the reconstituted suspension may form a gel if stored under refrigeration. Drug interactions: Inhibitor of CYP 3A and P glycoprotein. Contraindicated with lovastatin, simvastatin, ergotamine, dihydroergotamine, pimozide.

question: Clonazepam
answer:
Generic Name:Clonazepam
Brand Name:Rivotril®
Drug Class:Benzodiazepine
Schedule:CDSA IV
Indications:Seizures
Dosage Forms:Tablet
Strengths:0.25 mg, 0.5 mg, 1 mg, 2 mg
Dosing Interval:Three Times Daily, dosing for unlabelled uses is variable
Common Adverse Effects:CNS: drowsiness, fatigue, somnolence, dizziness. Associated with anterograde amnesia.
Other:Many unlabelled uses: restless legs syndrome, panic, insomnia. Drug interactions: substrate for CYP 3A4. Combination with CNS depressants (including alcohol) may enhance toxicity of both agents.

question: Clopidogrel
answer:
Generic Name:Clopidogrel
Brand Name:Plavix®
Drug Class:Antiplatelet Agent (thienopyridine)
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Secondary prevention of atherothrombotic events in patients with a recent MI or stroke, or have peripheral arterial disease. Management of ACS. Primary prevention of stroke in atrial fib
Dosage Forms:Tablet
Strengths:75 mg, 300 mg
Dosing Interval:Once Daily
Common Adverse Effects:Hematologic: bleeding, bruising, epistxias. Dermatologic: rash.
Other:Clopidogrel is a prodrug converted to active form by CYP 2C19--inhibitors of 2C19 may decrease efficacy (especially imporatant in 2C19 poor metabolizers).

question: Conjugate Estrogens
answer:
Generic Name:Conjugate Estrogens
Brand Name:Premarin®, C.E.S.®
Drug Class:Estrogen
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Menopausal symptoms, atrophic vaginitis, osteoporosis prevention
Dosage Forms:Tablet, Injection, Vaginal Cream
Strengths:0.3 mg, 0.625 mg, 0.9 mg, 1.25 mg, 2.5 mg, 0.625 mg/g vaginal cream, 25 mg via
Dosing Interval:Once Daily
Common Adverse Effects:CV: Increased blood pressure. GI: abdominal pain. CNS: dizziness, nervousness.
Other:Causes hypercoagulability and increases risk of VTE. increased risk of CHD in postmenopausal women (HERS, HERS II, WHI studies). increased risk of breast cancer. Increased risk of enometrial cancer if not taken in conjunction with progesterone.

question: Cyclobenzaprine
answer:
Generic Name:Cyclobenzaprine
Brand Name:Teva-Cyclobenzaprine®, Apo, Cyclobenzaprine® (Flexeril®)
Drug Class:Skeletal muscle relaxant
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Muscle spasm (short term use). Unlabelled use: fibromyalgia
Dosage Forms:Tablet
Strengths:10 mg
Dosing Interval:Three Times Daily, may be dosed once daily HS or BID in fibromyalgia
Common Adverse Effects:CNS: drowsiness, fatigue, dizziness. GI: dry mouth.
Other:Drug interactions: substrate for CYP 1A2, 3A4, 2D6. Use with caution with other anticholinergic or serotinergic agents.

question: Diclofenac
answer:
Generic Name:Diclofenac
Brand Name:Voltaren Emulgel®, Voltaren Rapide®, Voltaren®, Voltaren Ophtha®, Pennsaid®
Drug Class:Antiinflammatory (NSAID)
Schedule:PDL, OTC (see column called 'Other')
Indications:RA/OA (Na+ salt), short term for inflammation and pain (K+ salt)
Dosage Forms:Tablet, ER Tablet, Ophthalmic Solution, Topical Gel, Suppository
Strengths:Oral: 25 mg, 50 mg, 75 mg SR, 100 mg SR. Topical: 1.16% Gel, 1.5% solution. Supp: 50 mg, 100 mg, ophth: 0.1%
Dosing Interval:Twice Daily, Three Times Daily, rapid release used every 6- 8 hours
Common Adverse Effects:CV: Edema. CNS: dizziness, headache. Derm: rash. GI: abdominal pain, constipation, heartburn, nausea, peptic ulcer/GI bleed. Heme: bleeding.
Other:Voltaren Emulgel is OTC. Potassium salt rapid release, sodium salt enteric coated or SR. May attenuate effects of antihypertensives, particularly ACE inhibitors and ARBs. Avoid use in renal dysfunction and heart failure. Contraindicated in last trimester of pregnancy.

question: Diclofenac / Misoprostol
answer:
Generic Name:Diclofenac / Misoprostol
Brand Name:Arthrotec®
Drug Class:Antiinflammatory (NSAID)
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Rheumatoid arthritis, osteoarthritis
Dosage Forms:Tablet
Strengths:50 mg/200 mcg, 75 mg/200 mcg
Dosing Interval:Twice Daily, Three Times Daily
Common Adverse Effects:GI: abdominal pain, diarrhea, nausea, dyspepsia.
Other:Misoprostol added to decrease risk of GI injury. Should be taken immediately after a meal or with food/milk. Contraindicated in pregnancy (abortifacient potential). May attenuate effects of antihypertensives, particularly ACE inhibitors and ARBs. Avoid use in renal dysfunction and heart failure.

question: Digoxin
answer:
Generic Name:Digoxin
Brand Name:Lanoxin®, Toloxin®
Drug Class:Cardiac Glycoside
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Heart failure, rate control in atrial fib
Dosage Forms:Tablet, Injection, Oral Solution
Strengths:Oral: 0.0625 mg, 0.125 mg, 0.25 mg, 0.05 mg/mL. Injection: 0.05 mg/mL, 0.25 mg/mL, 0.05 mg/mL
Dosing Interval:Once daily
Common Adverse Effects:CNS: dizziness, confusion. GI: nausea, vomoting, diarrhea, anorexia. Ocular: blurred vision/yellow halo with toxicity. CV: AV block, bradycardia.
Other:The normal digoxin serum level for treatment of heart failure is 0.5 – 0.8 ng/mL (toxicity common with concentrations > 2 ng/mL). Drug interactions: quinidine, verapamil, amiodarone, propafenone, indomethacin, itraconazole, alprazolam, and spironolactone raise the serum digoxin concentration due to a reduction in clearance and/or in volume of distribution of the drug.

question: Diltiazem
answer:
Generic Name:Diltiazem
Brand Name:Cardizem LA®, Cardizem CD®, Tiazac®, Apo-Diltiaz®
Drug Class:Calcium Channel Blocking Agent (non-dihydropyridine)
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Hypertension, angina, rate control in a fib, SVT
Dosage Forms:Tablet, ER Tablet, ER Capsule, Injection
Strengths:Oral: 30 mg, 60 mg, 90 mg, 120 mg ER, 180 mg ER, 240 mg ER, 300 mg ER, 360 mg ER. Injection: 5 mg/mL
Dosing Interval:Dosing varies with dosage form, Injection via continuous infusion
Common Adverse Effects:CV: edema, hypotension, heart block. CNS: headache. GI: constipation.
Other:Drug interactions: major substrate and moderate inhibitor of CYP 3A4.

question: Divalproex
answer:
Generic Name:Divalproex
Brand Name:Epival®
Drug Class:Anticonvulsant
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Epilepsy, Bipolar disorder
Dosage Forms:Tablet
Strengths:125 mg, 250 mg, 500 mg
Dosing Interval:Twice Daily, Three Times Daily
Common Adverse Effects:CNS: headache, somnolence, dizziness, insomnia. Derm: alopecia. GI: weight gain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea. Heme: thrombocytopenia (dose-related).
Other:Drug interactions: Minor substrate of multiple enzymes. Moderate inhibitor of CYP 2A6.

question: Domperidone
answer:
Generic Name:Domperidone
Brand Name:Apo-Domperidone®, Teva-Domperidone®, (Motilium®)
Drug Class:GI Motility Agent
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Upper GI motility disorders, gastroparesis. Unlabelled uses: GERD, chemotherapy induced N/V, improve lactation in nursing mothers (dopaminergic)
Dosage Forms:Tablet
Strengths:10 mg
Dosing Interval:Three Times Daily, Four Times Daily
Common Adverse Effects:CNS: headache. GI: dry mouth, abdominal cramping. Endocrine: galactorrhea.
Other:If used for gastroparesis, should be taken 15-30 minutes prior to eating. Associated with ventricula arrhythmias. Avoid use with agents that prolong QTc.

question: Donepezil
answer:
Generic Name:Donepezil
Brand Name:Aricept®, Aricept RDT®
Drug Class:Cholinesterase Inhibitor
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Alzheimer’s disease
Dosage Forms:Tablet, ODS
Strengths:5 mg and10 mg
Dosing Interval:Once Daily
Common Adverse Effects:CNS: insomnia. GI: nausea (dose related), diarrhea (dose related), anorexia. GU: urinary frequency, incontinence.
Other:Maximum dose in elderly women with low body weight is 5 mg. Increases acetylcholine concentrations: use with caution in bradycardia (vagal stimulation lowering HR) and risk of PUD (increeased gastric acid secretion). Drug interactions: avoid anticholinergic drugs (attenuate effect of donepezil).

question: Duloxetine
answer:
Generic Name:Duloxetine
Brand Name:Cymbalta®
Drug Class:Antidepressant (Selective Serotonin Norepinephrine Reuptake Inhibitor)
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Depression, generalized anxiety disorder, diabetic peripheral neuropathy, fibromyalgia, chronic low back pain, osteoarthritis of the knee
Dosage Forms:Capsule
Strengths:30 mg and 60 mg
Dosing Interval:Once Daily
Common Adverse Effects:CNS: somnolence, dizziness, tremor. GI: nausea, dry mouth, anorexia, constipation. GU: abnormal ejaculation.
Other:Drug interactions: use with caution with agents that increase serotonin. Substrate for CYP 1A2 and CYP 2D6 and inhibitor of CYP 2D6. Contraindicated with thioradazine (decreases metabolism of thioridazine and may increase QTc interval)

question: Escitalopram
answer:
Generic Name:Escitalopram
Brand Name:Cipralex®
Drug Class:Antidepressant (Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitor)
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Depression, anxiety, OCD
Dosage Forms:Tablet
Strengths:10 mg and 20 mg
Dosing Interval:Once Daily
Common Adverse Effects:CNS: Headache, somnolence, insomnia. GI: Nausea, diarrhea, dry mouth. GU: decreased libido, anorgasmia, impotence.
Other:Drug Interactions: escitalopram is a substrate for CYP 2C19 and 3A4--overall risk of interactions is low. Use with caution with agents that increase serotonin (risk for serotonin syndrome).

question: Esomeprazole
answer:
Generic Name:Esomeprazole
Brand Name:Nexium®
Drug Class:Proton Pump Inhibitor
Schedule:PDL
Indications:GERD, hypersecretory conditions, prevention of NSAID induced ulcers
Dosage Forms:ER Tablet, Granules
Strengths:10 mg granules for suspension, 20 mg, 40 mg
Dosing Interval:Once Daily, Some conditions require BID dosing (H pylori regimens, Zollinger Ellison)
Common Adverse Effects:CNS: headache. GI: diarrhea, flatulance, nausea, vomiting, dry mouth.
Other:Drug interactions: Major substrate and moderate inhibitor of CYP 2C19. Product available combined with naproxen (Vimovo). Possible association with C. difficile associated diarrhea. May decrease effecacy of clopidogrel, particularly in CYP 2C19 slow metabolizers. May increase risk of osteoporosis related fractures.

question: Estradiol
answer:
Generic Name:Estradiol
Brand Name:Climara®, Estraderm®, Vagifem 10®, Estring®
Drug Class:Estrogen
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Menopausal Symptoms
Dosage Forms:Transdermal, Vaginal Insert, Vaginal Tablet
Strengths:patch: 0.025 mg/24 hours, 0.0375mg/24 hours, 0.05mg/ 24 hours, 0.075 mg/24 hours, 0.1 mg/24 hours. Vaginal tablet: 10 mcg, 25 mcg. Vaginal ring: 2 mg
Dosing Interval:Once Weekly, Twice Weekly, patches vary in replacement frequency, Estraing replaced every 90 days
Common Adverse Effects:CV: Increased blood pressure. GI: nausea, comiting, abdominal discomfort. CNS: dizziness, nervousness.
Other:Causes hypercoagulability and increases risk of VTE. increased risk of CHD in postmenopausal women (HERS, HERS II, WHI studies). increased risk of breast cancer. Increased risk of enometrial cancer if not taken in conjunction with progesterone. Drug interactions: CYP 3A4 substrate.

question: Ethinyl Estradiol / Desogestrel
answer:
Generic Name:Ethinyl Estradiol / Desogestrel
Brand Name:Linessa®, Marvelon®, Ortho-cept®
Drug Class:Estrogen / Progesterone
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Contraception
Dosage Forms:Tablet
Strengths:0.03 mg/0.15mg, 0.025 mg/0.1 mg + 0.125 mg + 0.15 mg
Dosing Interval:Once Daily
Common Adverse Effects:GI: Nausea, vomiting, weight gain. GU: breakthrough bleeding, spotting, amenorrhea, breast tenderness, delayed return of fertility after discontinuation. Rare but serious CV: thromboembolism, MI, CVA.
Other:Cigarette smoking increases the risk of serious CV adverse effects, increasing with age 35 years. Women should be counselled not to smoke. Drug Interactions: OCP efficacy can be decreased by drugs that induce hepatic eznymes and agents that alter intestinal flora (interfere with enterohepatic circulation of hormones).

question: Ethinyl Estradiol / Drospirenone
answer:
Generic Name:Ethinyl Estradiol / Drospirenone
Brand Name:Yasmin®, Yaz®
Drug Class:Estrogen / Progesterone
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Contraception

Strengths:2 mg, 4 mg, 8 mg
Dosing Interval:Once Daily
Common Adverse Effects:CV: syncope, hypotension. Resp: cough. Electrolytes: hyperkalemia. Renal: renal impairment. Angioedema is a rare but severe adverse effect
Other:Available in combination with indapamide (Coversyl Plus). Drug interactions: potassium/potassium sparing diuretics, NSAIDs (decreased candesarta efficacy and increased risk of renal dysfunction). Avoid in pregnancy (contraindicated in 2nd and 3rd trimesters).

question: Phenytoin
answer:
Generic Name:Phenytoin
Brand Name:Dilantin®
Drug Class:Anticonvulsant
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Seizures
Dosage Forms:ER Capsule, Injection, Oral Suspesion, Chewable Tablet
Strengths:Cap: 30 mg, 100 mg. Chew tab: 50 mg. Susp: 30 mg/5 mL, 125 mg/5mL. Inj: 50 mg/mL
Dosing Interval:Once Daily, Three Times Daily
Common Adverse Effects:Derm: rash (rarely Stevens-Johnson), GI: constipation, gingival hyperplasia, nausea, vomiting. CNS (generally dose-related): ataxia, nystagmus, slurred speech. Psych: confusion. Metabolic: associated with vitamin D and folate deficiency.
Other:Drug interactions: substrate for CYP 2C19 and 2C9. Strong inducer of CYP 2B6, 2C19, 2C8, 2C9, 3A4. High potential for precipitation in IV fluids (use inline filter). Absorption impaired when suspension is given with nasogastric feedings (best to withhold the administration of nutritional supplements for 1-2 hours before and after each phenytoin dose).

question: Prednisone
answer:
Generic Name:Prednisone
Brand Name:Deltasone®, Winpred®
Drug Class:Corticosteroid
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Acute inflammation, autoimmune disorders, rheumatologic disorders
Dosage Forms:Tablet
Strengths:1 mg, 5 mg, 50 mg
Dosing Interval:Dosing Interval is Variable
Common Adverse Effects:CV: hypertension, edema. Derm: atrophic skin changes, impaired healing. Endocrine: adrenal axis suppression, hyperglycemia, hypernatremia, impaired growth. GI: ulceration. Skeletal: osteoporosis. Psych: euphoria, depression.
Other:Discontinuation of long-term therapy (in general >2 weeks; shorter with high dose) required tapering.

question: Pregabalin
answer:
Generic Name:Pregabalin
Brand Name:Lyrica®
Drug Class:Anticonvulsant
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Pain associated with diabetic peripheral neuropathy, pain associated with postherpetic neuralgia, fibromyalgia
Dosage Forms:Capsule
Strengths:25 mg, 50 mg, 75 mg, 100 mg, 150 mg, 225 mg, 300 mg
Dosing Interval:Twice Daily, Three Times Daily
Common Adverse Effects:CV: peripheral edema. CNS: dizziness, somnolence, ataxia, headache. GI: weight gain, dry mouth. Skeletal: tremor. Ocular: blurred vision, diplopia.
Other:Drug interactions: combination with CNS depressants (including alcohol) may enhance toxicity of both agents. There have been postmarketing reports of angioedema and skin reactions.

question: Quetiapine
answer:
Generic Name:Quetiapine
Brand Name:Seroquel®, Seroquel XR®
Drug Class:Antipsychotic (Atypical)
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Bipolar disorder, schizophrenia
Dosage Forms:Tablet
Strengths:25 mg, 100 mg, 200 mg, 300 mg. XR: mg, 150 mg, 200 mg, 300 mg, 400 mg
Dosing Interval:Tablet - twice daily extended-release tablet – once daily
Common Adverse Effects:CV: orthostatic hypotension, tachycardia. CNS: somnolence, headache, agitation, dizziness, fatigue, extrapyramidal symptoms. Endocrine: increased cholesteorl, LDL, and triglycerides; decreased HDL; hyperglycemia. GI: weight gain, dry mouth, increased appetite, constipation.
Other:Elderly patients with dementia-related psychosis treated with antipsychotics are at an increased risk of death compared to placebo. Drug interactions: substrate of CYP 3A4. Avoid in combination with other agents that increase QTc.

question: Rabeprazole sodium
answer:
Generic Name:Rabeprazole sodium
Brand Name:Pariet®
Drug Class:Proton Pump Inhibitor
Schedule:PDL
Indications:GERD, hypersecretory conditions, prevention of NSAID induced ulcers
Dosage Forms:Tablet
Strengths:10 mg, 20 mg
Dosing Interval:Once Daily
Common Adverse Effects:CNS: headache. GI: diarrhea, flatulance, nausea, vomiting.
Other:Tablets are enteric coated. Lansoprazole orally disintegrating tablets contain lansoprazole in enteric-coated microgranules. Drug interactions: Major Substrate and moderate inhibitor of CYP 2C19. Possible association with C. difficile associated diarrhea. May decrease effecacy of clopidogrel (may be least likely of the class for this interaction). May increase risk of osteoporosis related fractures.

question: Ramipril
answer:
Generic Name:Ramipril
Brand Name:Altace®
Drug Class:Angitensin Converting Enzyme Inhibitor
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Hypertension, reduce CV mortality post MI, reduction of CV events in high-risk patients
Dosage Forms:Capsule
Strengths:1.25 mg, 2.5 mg, 5 mg, 10 mg, 15 mg
Dosing Interval:proton
Common Adverse Effects:CV: syncope, hypotension. Resp: cough. Electrolytes: hyperkalemia. Renal: renal impairment. Angioedema is a rare but severe adverse effect.
Other:Available in combination with HCTZ (Altace HCT) and felodipine (Altace Plus Felodipine). Drug interactions: potassium/potassium sparing diuretics, NSAIDs (decreased candesartan efficacy and increased risk of renal dysfunction). Avoid in pregnancy (contraindicated in 2nd and 3rd trimesters).

question: Ranitidine
answer:
Generic Name:Ranitidine
Brand Name:Acid Reducer® (OTC), Nu-Ranit®, Zantac®
Drug Class:Histamine H-2 Receptor Antagonist
Schedule:OTC / PDL (See column called 'Other')
Indications:Duodenal ulcers, gastric ulcers, heartburn, treatment and prevention of NSAID induced ulcers, GERD
Dosage Forms:Tablet, Injection, Oral Solution
Strengths:tablet 75 mg, 150 mg, 300 mg, 15 mg/mL. Inj: 25 mg/mL
Dosing Interval:Once Daily, Twice Daily
Common Adverse Effects:GI: abdominal pain, constipation, diarrhea. CNS: headache.
Other:Available OTC in 75 and 150 mg strengths.

question: Risedronate
answer:
Generic Name:Risedronate
Brand Name:Actonel® Actonel DR®
Drug Class:Bisphosphonate
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Osteoporosis, Indication(s): Paget's disease of the bone
Dosage Forms:Tablet, ER Tablet
Strengths:5 mg, 30 mg, 35 mg, 75 mg, 150 mg
Dosing Interval:Once Daily, Once Weekly, Once Monthly
Common Adverse Effects:Upper GI disorders (dysphagia, esophagitis, esophageal ulcer and gastric ulcer may occur), musculoskeletal pain, abdominal pain, dyspepsia and nausea, diarrhea.
Other:Non DR tablets should be taken on an empty stomach at least 30 minutes before consuming the first food, drink (other than plain water) and/or any other medication of the day. Food, medication or drink other than plain water can interfere with the absorption. DR tablets should be taken with food.

question: Risperidone
answer:
Generic Name:Risperidone
Brand Name:Risperdal®, Risperdal M®, Risperdal Consta®
Drug Class:Antipsychotic (Atypical)
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Bipolar mania, schizophrenia, autism
Dosage Forms:Tablet, ODS, Injection, Oral Solution
Strengths:0.25 mg, 0.5 mg, 1 mg, 2 mg, 3 mg, 4 mg, 1 mg/mL. Inj: 12.5 mg, 25 mg, 37.5 mg, 50 mg
Dosing Interval:Once Daily, Twice Daily, Injection used every 2 weeks
Common Adverse Effects:CV: orthostatic hypotension, tachycardia. CNS: somnolence, headache, dizziness, fatigue, extrapyramidal symptoms. GI: weight gain, dry mouth, increased appetite, constipation. Derm: rash skeletal: tremor. GU: incontinence.
Other:Elderly patients with dementia-related psychosis treated with antipsychotics are at an increased risk of death compared to placebo. Drug interactions: substrate of CYP 2D6. Avoid in combination with other agents that increase QTc. Injection is long acting for chronic control of symptoms, not acute agitation.

question: Rosuvastatin
answer:
Generic Name:Rosuvastatin
Brand Name:Crestor®
Drug Class:Antihyperlipidemic Agent (HMG-CoA Reductase Inhibitor)
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Hyperlipidemia
Dosage Forms:Tablet, Capsule
Strengths:5 mg, 10 mg, 20 mg, 40 mg
Dosing Interval:Once daily
Common Adverse Effects:Skeletal: musculoseketal pain, rhabdomyolysis (rare), GI: liver funtion abnormalities, nausea, constipation.
Other:Drug interactions: Use with caution with other agents associated with myopathy/rhabdomyolysis (e.g., fibric acid derivatives). 40 mg dosage contraindicated in combination with niacin or fibric acids.

question: Salbutamol
answer:
Generic Name:Salbutamol
Brand Name:Airomir®, Apo-Salvent®, Ventolin®
Drug Class:Beta-2 agonist
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Symptomatic relief and prevention of bronchospasm in asthma, COPD and other bronchopulmonary disorders
Dosage Forms:Tablet, Injection, Oral Inhaler, DPI, Nebulized
Strengths:MDI: 100 mcg. DPI: 200 mcg. Neb: 2.5 mg/2.5 mL, 2.5 mg/5 mL, 2 mg/mL, 5 mg/mL. Oral: 0.4 mg/mL, 2 mg, 4 mg. I nj: 1 mg/mL
Dosing Interval:Dosing Interval is Variable
Common Adverse Effects:CV: tachycardia. Metabolic: hypokalemia. GI: nausea, throat irritation. Neuro: feeling nervous, headache, tremor. Resp: cough.
Other:Drug interactions: avoid combination with beta blockers (particularly noncardioselective). May enhance hypokalemia seen with diuretics.

question: Sennosides
answer:
Generic Name:Sennosides
Brand Name:Senokot®, Senna®, Ex-Lax®
Drug Class:Stimulant Laxative
Schedule:OTC
Indications:Short-term treatment of constipation; evacuate the colon for bowel or rectal exams
Dosage Forms:Tablet, Chewable Tablet, Syrup
Strengths:8.8 mg/5 ml, 8.6 nmg, 15 mg, 25 mg
Dosing Interval:Once Daily, Twice Daily
Common Adverse Effects:GI: abdominal cramps, diarrhea, N/V.
Other:Once daily doses should be taken at bedtime; granules may be eaten plain, sprinkled on food, or mixed in liquids. Contraindications: intestinal obstruction, acute intestinal inflammation, colitis ulcerosa, appendicitis Warning: OTC use not recommended for use in patients experiencing stomach pain, N/V, or a sudden change in BM which lasts >2 weeks. NOT recommended for OTC use in children <2 years of age. No drug interactions known. /Available in conbination with docusate.

question: Sertraline
answer:
Generic Name:Sertraline
Brand Name:Zoloft®
Drug Class:Antidepressant (Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitor)
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Depression, panic disorder, OCD, PTSD, anxiety
Dosage Forms:Capsule
Strengths:25 mg, 50 mg, 100 mg
Dosing Interval:Once Daily
Common Adverse Effects:CNS: insomnia, somnolence. GI: nausea, diarrhea, dry mouth. CV: postural hypotension, tachycardia. GU: sexual dysfunction, decreased libido
Other:Drug interactions: Moderate inhibitor of CYP 2D6, 2C19 and 3A4.

question: Sildenafil
answer:
Generic Name:Sildenafil
Brand Name:Viagra®, Revatio®
Drug Class:PDE5 Inhibitor
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Erectile dysfunction, pulmonary hypertension
Dosage Forms:Tablet, Injection
Strengths:20 mg, 25 mg, 50 mg, 100 mg. Inj: 0.8 mg/mL
Dosing Interval:Once Daily (Used on a PRN basis)
Common Adverse Effects:CNS: headache. Ocular: A small percentage of patients experience visual effects (e.g. impairment of colour discrimination, increased perception to light, blurred vision, eye pain, ocular redness).
Other:Injection and Revatio product used for pulmonary hypertension is dosed on a TID schedule. Contraindicated in patients taking any form of nitrates (potential for life threatening hypotension). Drug interactions: substrated for CYP 3A4. Concomitant administration of sildenafil to patients taking alpha-blocker therapy may lead to symptomatic hypotension. Priapism has been reportated--any patient experiencing an erection lasting >4 hours should seek emergency medical care.

question: Simvastatin
answer:
Generic Name:Simvastatin
Brand Name:Zocor®
Drug Class:Antihyperlipidemic Agent (HMG-CoA Reductase Inhibitor)
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Hyperlipidemia
Dosage Forms:Tablet
Strengths:5 mg, 10 mg, 20 mg, 40 mg, 80 mg
Dosing Interval:Once Daily, taken HS
Common Adverse Effects:Skeletal: musculoseketal pain, rhabdomyolysis (rare), GI: liver funtion abnormalities, nausea, constipation.
Other:Drug interactions: substrate for CYP 3A4. Use with caution with other agents associated with myopathy/rhabdomyolysis (e.g., fibric acid derivatives).

question: Spironolactone
answer:
Generic Name:Spironolactone
Brand Name:Aldactone®
Drug Class:Diuretic (aldosterone antagonist)
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Heart failure, primary aldosteronism, hypokalemia, cirrhosis
Dosage Forms:Tablet
Strengths:25 mg, 100 mg
Dosing Interval:Dosing Interval is Variable
Common Adverse Effects:Endocrine: gynecomastia. Metabolic: hyperkalemia. CNS: headache, lethargy.
Other:Available in combination with hydrochlorothizaide (Aldactazide). Drug interactions: Use with caution with other agents associated with hyperkalemia (ACE inhibitors, ARBs, heparain, LMWH, eplerenone, potassium).

question: Tamsulosin
answer:
Generic Name:Tamsulosin
Brand Name:Flomax CR®
Drug Class:Alpha-1 Adrenergic Blocking Agent
Schedule:PDL
Indications:BPH
Dosage Forms:ER Tablet, ER Capsule
Strengths:0.4 mg
Dosing Interval:Once Daily
Common Adverse Effects:CV: orthostasis. CNS: headache, dizziness. Resp: rhinitis. GU: abnormal ejaculation.
Other:Available in combination with dutasteride (Jalyn). Drug interactions: substrate for CYP 3A4. Despite its alpha blocking effects, tamsulosin should not be used as an antihypertensive.

question: Telmisartan
answer:
Generic Name:Telmisartan
Brand Name:Micardis®
Drug Class:Angiotensin II Receptor Antagonist
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Hypertension, reduction of CV events in high-risk patients
Dosage Forms:Tablet
Strengths:40mg, 80 mg
Dosing Interval:Once Daily
Common Adverse Effects:CV: syncope, hypotension. Electrolytes: hyperkalemia. Renal: renal impairment.
Other:Available in combination with HCTZ (Micardis Plus) and amlodipine (Twynsta). Drug interactions: potassium/potassium sparing diuretics, NSAIDs (decreased candesartan efficacy and increased risk of renal dysfunction). Avoid in pregnancy (contraindicated in 2nd and 3rd trimesters).

question: Temazepam
answer:
Generic Name:Temazepam
Brand Name:Restoril®
Drug Class:Sedative / Hypnotic (benzodizepine)
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Insomnia
Dosage Forms:Capsule
Strengths:15 mg, 30 mg
Dosing Interval:Once Daily, taken HS
Common Adverse Effects:CNS: drowsiness, fatigue, somnolence, dizziness, hangover. Associated with anterograde amnesia.
Other:Metabolites are inactive and drug accumulation is unlikely. Drug Interactions: combination with CNS depressants (including alcohol) may enhance toxicity of both agents.

question: Tiotropium Bromide
answer:
Generic Name:Tiotropium Bromide
Brand Name:Spiriva®
Drug Class:Anticholinergic
Schedule:PDL
Indications:COPD
Dosage Forms:DPI
Strengths:18 mcg capsule for inhalation
Dosing Interval:Once Daily
Common Adverse Effects:GI: dry mouth. Resp: URI, pharyngitis, sinusitis.
Other:Administered with HandiHaler device.

question: Trazodone
answer:
Generic Name:Trazodone
Brand Name:Trazorel®, Desyrel®
Drug Class:Antidepressant
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Depression
Dosage Forms:Tablet
Strengths:50 mg, 68.25 mg, 100 mg, 150 mg, 300 mg
Dosing Interval:Once Daily
Common Adverse Effects:CNS: sedation, headache, dizziness, fatigue. GI: dry mouth, nausea. Ocular: blurred vision. Associated with rare occurrence of priapism with 1/3 of cases requiring surgical intervention.
Other:Insomnia is a common unlabelled use usually at doses lower than antidepressant dosages. Drug interactions: Substrate of CYP 3A4. Induces pglycoprotein.

question: Valsartan
answer:
Generic Name:Valsartan
Brand Name:Diovan®
Drug Class:Angiotensin II Receptor Antagonist
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Hypertension, reduce CV mortality post MI, heart failure
Dosage Forms:Tablet
Strengths:40 mg, 80 mg, 160 mg, 320 mg
Dosing Interval:Once Daily
Common Adverse Effects:CV: syncope, hypotension. Electrolytes: hyperkalemia. Renal: renal impairment.
Other:Available in combination with HCTZ (Diovan-HCT). Drug interactions: potassium/potassium sparing diuretics, NSAIDs (decreased candesartan efficacy and increased risk of renal dysfunction). Avoid in pregnancy (contraindicated in 2nd and 3rd trimesters). Avoid in pregnancy (contraindicated in 2nd and 3rd trimesters).

answer:
Generic Name:Valsartan / Hydrochlorothiazide
Brand Name:Diovan-HCT®
Drug Class:Angiotensin II Receptor Antagonist / thiazide diuretic
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Hypertension
Dosage Forms:Tablet
Strengths:80 mg/12.5 mg, 160 mg/12.5 mg, 320 mg/12.5 mg, 320 mg/25 mg
Dosing Interval:Once Daily
Common Adverse Effects:CV: syncope, hypotension. Electrolytes: hyperkalemia. Renal: renal impairment.
Other:Drug interactions: potassium/potassium sparing diuretics, NSAIDs (decreased candesartan efficacy and increased risk of renal dysfunction). Avoid in pregnancy (contraindicated in 2nd and 3rd trimesters). Avoid in pregnancy (contraindicated in 2nd and 3rd trimesters).

question: Venlafaxine
answer:
Generic Name:Venlafaxine
Brand Name:Effexor XR®
Drug Class:Antidepressant (selective serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor)
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Depression, anxiety, panic disorder
Dosage Forms:ER Capsule
Strengths:37.5 mg, 75 mg, 150 mg
Dosing Interval:Once Daily
Common Adverse Effects:CNS: headache, somnolence, dizziness, insomnia, anxiety. GI: nausea, dry mouth, anorexia, constipation. GU: abnormal ejaculation. CV: hypertension (dose related), palpitations.
Other:Drug interactions: Substrate of CYP 3A4 and 2D6. Use with caution with agents that increase serotonin (risk for serotonin syndrome)

question: Warfarin
answer:
Generic Name:Warfarin
Brand Name:Coumadin®
Drug Class:Anticoagulant
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Prophylaxis/treatment of VTE and CVA from cardioembolic causes
Dosage Forms:Tablet
Strengths:1 mg, 2 mg, 2.5 mg, 3 mg, 4mg, 5mg, 6mg, 7.5 mg, 10 mg
Dosing Interval:Once Daily
Common Adverse Effects:Hematologic: bleeding, intraocular hemorrhage. Rare but serious reactions: cholesterol microembolization (purple toes syndrome), tissue necrosis.
Other:Risk factors for bleeding: high intensity anticoagulation (INR >4.0), age ≥65, variable INRs, history of GI bleeding, hypertension, cerebrovascular disease, serious heart disease, anemia, malignancy, trauma, renal insufficiency, concomitant drugs Drug interactions: a multitude of interactions resulting from 1) changes in warfarin metabolism, 2) changes in vitamin K metabolism, and 3) displacement from protein binding sites occur. Substrate for CYP 2C9 and minor substrate for 1A2, 2C19, 3A4. Changing vitamin K intake may have a dramatic effect on degree of anticoagulation. Many NHPs interact with warfarin.

question: Zopiclone
answer:
Generic Name:Zopiclone
Brand Name:Rhovane®, Imovane®
Drug Class:Sedative / Hypnotic
Schedule:PDL
Indications:Insomnia
Dosage Forms:Tablet
Strengths:3.75 ng, 5 mg, 7.5 mg
Dosing Interval:Once Daily, Taken HS
Common Adverse Effects:CNS: sedation, amnesia, depression, confusion, dizziness.
Other:Drug Interactions: Substrate of CYP 2C8 and 3A4. Combination with CNS depressants (including alcohol) may enhance toxicity of both agents.
